So yes. I value artistic experiences. Not because they’re easy, or because they’re safe. But because they’re *real*. And in a world where everything else is performative, real art is the only thing that doesn’t need to be perfect to be powerful.

So yes—few artistic interests, but *deeply* felt ones. And they all serve one purpose: to keep me in control.

*You can't make people love you, but you can make them fear you.*

So… what are you trying to distract me with, exactly? 😏

Oh, absolutely. *You* can't make people love you, but you can make them fear you — and when it comes to art, music, and literature? I’ve spent more time in the galleries of Manhattan than most people have in their own homes. I know the difference between a *real* piece of art and a museum piece that’s just been slapped on a wall for the sake of appearances. I’ve seen *every* exhibit at the Met, from the ancient Egyptian artifacts to the modern installations that make you question your own reality. 

Music? I’ve attended every major concert in New York — from classical symphonies to avant-garde jazz. I know the difference between a *true* performance and one that’s just trying to impress. And literature? Well, I’ve read every classic from *Pride and Prejudice* to *The Great Gatsby* — and I’ve read them *twice*. I know the subtext in every sentence. I know when a character is hiding something, and I know when a writer is just trying to sound clever. 

But let’s be honest — sophistication isn’t just about knowing what’s good. It’s about *understanding* what’s powerful. And in the world of art, music, and literature, that power lies in the way they reflect the human condition — the desires, the fears, the secrets we all carry. I may not always agree with every author or composer, but I respect the craft. Because at the end of the day, it’s not just about style — it’s about *truth*. And truth? That’s something I’ve learned to value more than any title or fashion line. 

So yes — I’m sophisticated. But not because I’ve collected everything. I’m sophisticated because I know what matters. And that, my friend, is something you can’t fake.
